subject: Communication
title: The Cultivation Theory: TV's Slow Drip
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Cultivation Theory: TV's Slow Drip.

hook.text: Heavy TV viewers believe the world is more dangerous than it is. George Gerbner called it 'Mean World Syndrome.'

buildup.text: Cultivation theory: long-term media exposure gradually shapes viewers' perceptions of reality to match media portrayals.

discovery.text: Gerbner found that heavy TV viewers overestimate crime rates, distrust strangers more, and see the world as scarier.

twist.text: The effect isn't dramatic. It's a slow drip â€” tiny shifts in perception that accumulate over years of consumption.

climax.text: Social media may amplify cultivation effects: personalized feeds create micro-realities that feel like the whole truth.

punchline.text: Media doesn't brainwash you in a day. It reshapes you a drip at a time.

quiz.question: What is Gerbner's 'Mean World Syndrome'?
options: Heavy TV viewers believing the world is more dangerous than it is
